fix(graphql): change CDN to JS Deliver for GraphiQL (#4941)

* fix(graphql): change CDN to JS Deliver for GraphiQL

* fix(graphql): add crossorigin prop
graph: Qualify uses of graphql parser types with s::

graph: Move InputSchema validations over from Schema

These validations only makes sense for input schemas, not generic GraphQL
schemas

all: Fix test schemas

Since validation of InputSchema isn't mandatory, many of the schemas we use
in our tests actually failed validation. This commit addresses that.
graph: Make it impossible to construct an unvalidated InputSchema

graph: Validate the id field of object types

This hadn't been done before, though in practice it was probably never
violated (presumably since graph-cli enforces such rules, and because
trying to deploy such a schema would end badly)

The `examples/validate.rs` is a tool that makes it possible to bulk
validate subgraph schemas.

issue.title: [Bug] Missing ABI reported as non-deterministic error
issue.body:
### Bug report

I tried deploying a graph with missing a ABI(ABI was added to just one data source but was used in handlers for other sources too) and the node was silently stuck in a block that needed this ABI. Upon inspecting the graph-node docker logs I saw the error `ERRO Subgraph failed with non-deterministic error: failed to process trigger: block #1877280 (0x9fc0…625a), transaction e4d73c7a0271f8efe2d44721ccdc4dbc78d7ee270ecda98f131959bfec9b69fb: Could not find ABI for contract "IERC721", try adding it to the 'abis' section of the subgraph manifest`. The node was still returning results and showing `"hasIndexingErrors": false` in _meta
Based on the docs for [failed subgraphs](https://thegraph.com/docs/en/operating-graph-node/#failed-subgraphs) missing ABI should be considered a "final" deterministic failures. From the docs:
> In some cases, the non-deterministic label is incorrect, and the subgraph will never overcome the error; such failures should be reported as issues on the Graph Node repository.

Hence reporting this issue. Using `graphprotocol/graph-node:v0.30.0`

### Relevant log output

```Shell
Oct 19 12:57:37.383 ERRO Subgraph failed with non-deterministic error: failed to process trigger: block #1877280 (0x9fc0…625a), transaction e4d73c7a0271f8efe2d44721ccdc4dbc78d7ee270ecda98f131959bfec9b69fb: Could not find ABI for contract "IERC721", try adding it to the 'abis' section of the subgraph manifest	wasm backtrace:	    0: 0x37b3 - <unknown>!~lib/@graphprotocol/graph-ts/chain/ethereum/ethereum.SmartContract#tryCall	    1: 0x3fb9 - <unknown>!src/fetch/erc721/fetchERC721Token	    2: 0x4632 - <unknown>!src/mappings/asksV1/handleAskCreated	, retry_delay_s: 1800, attempt: 6, sgd: 172, subgraph_id: QmRhxkAhYDEgwY9JcV7vyZDomtJcpaF2aXCBL6xm6PbEfj, component: SubgraphInstanceManager
```


### IPFS hash

_No response_

### Subgraph name or link to explorer

_No response_

### Some information to help us out

- [ ] Tick this box if this bug is caused by a regression found in the latest release.
- [ ] Tick this box if this bug is specific to the hosted service.
- [X] I have searched the issue tracker to make sure this issue is not a duplicate.

### OS information

None

comment.body: Created a minimal reproducible example on subgraph studio https://thegraph.com/studio/subgraph/missing-abi-nondeter-bug-4928 (build: `QmQuo2q2dEU9J6qi7no7Pe6tTMD4t3beedRzSjyJt1GPc2`) Not sure whether you can access the graph details, so here's the code: - package.json ``` "name": "redacted", "license": "UNLICENSED", "scripts": { "codegen": "graph codegen", "build": "graph build", "test": "graph test" }, "dependencies": { "@amxx/graphprotocol-utils": "^1.1.0", "@openzeppelin/contracts": "^5.0.0" }, "devDependencies": { "@graphprotocol/graph-cli": "0.60.0", "@graphprotocol/graph-ts": "0.31.0", "matchstick-as": "0.5.0" } } ``` - subgraph.yaml ``` specVersion: 0.0.4 schema: file: ./schema.graphql dataSources: - kind: ethereum name: punks network: mainnet source: abi: Punks startBlock: 18434892 mapping: kind: ethereum/events apiVersion: 0.0.6 language: wasm/assemblyscript entities: - Punk abis: - name: Punks file: ./abis/punks.json - name: IERC721 file: node_modules/@openzeppelin/contracts/build/contracts/IERC721Metadata.json eventHandlers: - event: PunkTransfer(indexed address,indexed address,uint256) handler: handlePunkTransfer file: ./src/punks.ts - kind: ethereum name: beanz network: mainnet source: abi: Beanz startBlock: 18434892 mapping: kind: ethereum/events apiVersion: 0.0.6 language: wasm/assemblyscript entities: - Bean abis: - name: Beanz file: ./abis/beanz.json eventHandlers: - event: Transfer(indexed address,indexed address,indexed uint256) handler: handleTransfer file: ./src/beanz.ts ``` - schema.graphql ``` type Punk @entity { id: ID! name: String! number: BigInt! uri: String } type Bean @entity { id: ID! name: String! number: BigInt! uri: String } ``` - src/punks.ts ``` import { Address } from "@graphprotocol/graph-ts"; import {IERC721} from "../generated/punks/IERC721" import {PunkTransfer} from "../generated/punks/Punks" import {Punk} from "../generated/schema" export function handlePunkTransfer(event: PunkTransfer): void { const punk = new Punk(event.params.punkIndex.toString()); punk.name = `Punk - ${event.params.punkIndex.toString()}`; punk.number = event.params.punkIndex; const contract = IERC721.bind(Address.fromString("0x8821BeE2ba0dF28761AffF119D66390D594CD280")) const tryTokenUri = contract.try_tokenURI(event.params.punkIndex); if (!tryTokenUri.reverted) { punk.uri = tryTokenUri.value; } punk.save(); } ``` - src/beanz.ts ``` import { Address } from "@graphprotocol/graph-ts"; import {IERC721} from "../generated/punks/IERC721" import {Transfer} from "../generated/beanz/Beanz" import { Bean } from "../generated/schema" export function handleTransfer(event: Transfer): void { const bean = new Bean(event.params.tokenId.toString()); bean.name = `Bean - ${event.params.tokenId.toString()}`; bean.number = event.params.tokenId; if ("get me an error") { const contract = IERC721.bind(Address.fromString("0x8821BeE2ba0dF28761AffF119D66390D594CD280")) const tryTokenUri = contract.try_tokenURI(event.params.tokenId); if (!tryTokenUri.reverted) { bean.uri = tryTokenUri.value; } } bean.save(); } ``` ABI for [beanz](https://etherscan.io/address/0x306b1ea3ecdf94ab739f1910bbda052ed4a9f949#code) and [punks](https://etherscan.io/address/0xb47e3cd837ddf8e4c57f05d70ab865de6e193bbb#code) The main difference between both datasources is that punks has `IERC721` referenced in the ABI section whereas beanz doesn't. In `src/beanz.ts` see the following if condition in the line `if ("get me an error")`. When this is commented out(deployed with tag 0.0.3) it works, but then that condition is run (tagged 0.0.4) I see an error in subgraph studio But in the logs it is mentioned as a "non-deterministic" error and continues to retry indexing (Not sure what happened to attempt 2 🤷 ) Note that beanz.ts imports from the generated files for punks.

issue.title: Make the load manager work for sharded setups
issue.body: The [`LoadManager`](https://github.com/graphprotocol/graph-node/blob/master/graph/src/data/graphql/effort.rs#L189) tries to determine when the system enters an overloaded state and drops queries in that case. Unfortunately, the data it bases its decisions on was never fully updated to take multiple shards into account and it seems that it therefore never notices when a shard has high load.

issue.title: Make the load manager work for sharded setups
issue.body: The [`LoadManager`](https://github.com/graphprotocol/graph-node/blob/master/graph/src/data/graphql/effort.rs#L189) tries to determine when the system enters an overloaded state and drops queries in that case. Unfortunately, the data it bases its decisions on was never fully updated to take multiple shards into account and it seems that it therefore never notices when a shard has high load.

issue.title: Define an `IdValue` enum and use that everywhere where we pass ids around
issue.body:
### Description

Currently, when a subgraph uses `Bytes` as the type for the `id`, we internally use the string representation of that in a lot of places, for example in `EntityKey.entity_id`. That can cause a lot of confusion since it's never clear whether the string representation should start with `0x` or not.

Instead, we should have an enum
```rust
enum IdValue {
  String(Word),
  Bytes(Bytes)
}
```

and use that wherever we deal with entity ids.

One issue caused by this confusion is #4661

issue.title: Define an `IdValue` enum and use that everywhere where we pass ids around
issue.body:
### Description

Currently, when a subgraph uses `Bytes` as the type for the `id`, we internally use the string representation of that in a lot of places, for example in `EntityKey.entity_id`. That can cause a lot of confusion since it's never clear whether the string representation should start with `0x` or not.

Instead, we should have an enum
```rust
enum IdValue {
  String(Word),
  Bytes(Bytes)
}
```

and use that wherever we deal with entity ids.

One issue caused by this confusion is #4661

comment.body: These was done as part of #4883

issue.title: [Feature] Add a `graphman database check`
issue.body:
### Description

We should add a `graphman` command that checks that all shards can talk to each other in the way that we need. For each shard, it should access the `primary_public` (e.g., by running `select count(*) from primary_public.chains`) and the `shard_.._subgraphs.subgraph` tables for all the other shards and print any error it encounters.

This would be very useful to ensure that everything is in place for sharding to work as there are many ways in which this can go wrong (firewalls, `pg_hba.conf`, ..)

### Are you aware of any blockers that must be resolved before implementing this feature? If so, which? Link to any relevant GitHub issues.

_No response_

### Some information to help us out

- [ ] Tick this box if you plan on implementing this feature yourself.
- [X] I have searched the issue tracker to make sure this issue is not a duplicate.

comment.body: On second thought, I wonder if we shouldn't just do these checks every time `graph-node` starts and complain loudly if one of them fails. A problem in cross-shard comms will later show up as weird issues in other operations (e.g., copies not starting for seemingly no reason)

issue.title: [Feature] Add more labels to `deployment_sync_secs`
issue.body:
### Description

The `deployment_sync_secs` metric measures indexing speed. We should add the following labels to it:

* `sgd`: the internal identifier of the deployment to disambiguate copies of the same IPFS hash
* `shard`: the shard in which the deployment lives so that we can aggregate by shard and hopefully use that to better understand when indexing in a specific shard becomes slow


### Are you aware of any blockers that must be resolved before implementing this feature? If so, which? Link to any relevant GitHub issues.

_No response_

### Some information to help us out

- [ ] Tick this box if you plan on implementing this feature yourself.
- [X] I have searched the issue tracker to make sure this issue is not a duplicate.

issue.title: [Feature] Support Substreams on networks where no `chain` implementation exists yet in `graph-node`
issue.body:
### Description

This is a follow up of #4302 see it for general description. See also https://github.com/graphprotocol/graph-node/issues/4302#issuecomment-1632714489 which could be used to implement a `SubstreamsBlockIngestor`, one of the main problem in solving this issue.

First objective of this would be to support Solana Substreams powered Subgraph.

### Are you aware of any blockers that must be resolved before implementing this feature? If so, which? Link to any relevant GitHub issues.

_No response_

### Some information to help us out

- [ ] Tick this box if you plan on implementing this feature yourself.
- [X] I have searched the issue tracker to make sure this issue is not a duplicate.

comment.body:
Seems that 0 not respected by Substreams is actually a backend problem as Firehose accepts this and we made already some change to accepte `initialBlock: 0` as chain's genesis.

Tracked via https://github.com/streamingfast/substreams/issues/290#issuecomment-1781728171, I think we will be good to go after that.
I don't see a reason why it wouldn't be done that way - each level with increased details. Maybe the info could be even more condensed...

issue.title: [Bug] Substreams block ingestor seems to start at 0
issue.body:
### Bug report

I started a `graph-node` with a Substreams only config:

```
[general]

[store]
[store.primary]
connection = "postgresql://graph-node:let-me-in@localhost:5432/graph-node"
weight = 1
pool_size = 10

[chains]
ingestor = "block_ingestor_node"
[chains.sol-mainnet]
protocol = "substreams"
shard = "primary"
provider = [
    { label = "substreams", details = { type = "substreams", url = "https://mainnet.eth.streamingfast.io:443", token = "$SUBSTREAMS_API_TOKEN", features = [
        "compression",
        "filters",
    ], conn_pool_size = 1 } },
]

[deployment]
[[deployment.rule]]
shard = "primary"
indexers = ["default"]
```

When `graph-node` starts on a fresh database, I can see block received starting on the log end of the chain. As far as I remember, the other ingestor starts on live block.

Here some logs using [maoueh/investigate-stuck-substreams](https://github.com/graphprotocol/graph-node/tree/maoueh/investigate-stuck-substreams) which has a log on each message received which made me realized this:

```
Oct 26 11:13:40.060 INFO Blockstreams disconnected, connecting, provider_err_count: 0, cursor: , start_block: 0, subgraph: , endpoint_uri: substreams, provider: substreams, deployment: , component:
Oct 26 11:13:40.204 INFO Blockstreams connected, provider: substreams, deployment: , component:
Oct 26 11:13:40.206 INFO Waiting for next response, provider: substreams, deployment: , component:
Oct 26 11:13:40.206 INFO Next response received Session: SessionInit { trace_id: "d5f817488ad98e5b99720ea677d90215", resolved_start_block: 0, linear_handoff_block: 18435000, max_parallel_workers: 75 }, provider: substreams, deployment: , component:
Oct 26 11:13:40.206 INFO Received session init, session: SessionInit { trace_id: "d5f817488ad98e5b99720ea677d90215", resolved_start_block: 0, linear_handoff_block: 18435000, max_parallel_workers: 75 }, provider: substreams, deployment: , component:
Oct 26 11:13:40.207 INFO Waiting for next response, trace_id: d5f817488ad98e5b99720ea677d90215, provider: substreams, deployment: , component:
Oct 26 11:13:40.362 INFO Next response received Block  #0 (d4e56740f876aef8c010b86a40d5f56745a118d0906a34e69aec8c0db1cb8fa3), trace_id: d5f817488ad98e5b99720ea677d90215, provider: substreams, deployment: , component:
Oct 26 11:13:40.423 INFO Waiting for next response, trace_id: d5f817488ad98e5b99720ea677d90215, provider: substreams, deployment: , component:
Oct 26 11:13:40.428 INFO Next response received Block  #1 (88e96d4537bea4d9c05d12549907b32561d3bf31f45aae734cdc119f13406cb6), trace_id: d5f817488ad98e5b99720ea677d90215, provider: substreams, deployment: , component:
```

### Relevant log output

_No response_

### IPFS hash

_No response_

### Subgraph name or link to explorer

_No response_

### Some information to help us out

- [ ] Tick this box if this bug is caused by a regression found in the latest release.
- [ ] Tick this box if this bug is specific to the hosted service.
- [X] I have searched the issue tracker to make sure this issue is not a duplicate.

issue.title: [Bug] Investigate in-memory caching of blocks
issue.body:
### Bug report

We recently added a way to cache blocks in memory (#4215) though it looks like that did not have the desired effect. We also added metrics (#4440 ) to better understand how that cache works. 

We need to figure out why this cache isn't effective. The underlying issue that needs to be addressed is that reading from the block cache in the database can require a lot of IO bandwidth, and we need to reduce that.

comment.body: Not really, I'm afraid. The high IO load came from a different set of queries after the deployment, that much I remember – which probably means some problematic queries were optimized away but not nearly enough to reduce the IO load. We never started an actual follow-up investigation beyond that.

issue.title: [Bug] `net_version` change error when switching from `RPC` provider to a Firehose provider
issue.body:
### Bug report

Steps:
1. Fresh `graph-node` start from fresh database with config below. This creates a chain for mainnet with `net_version: 1` in the database.

    ```
    [general]
    
    [store]
    [store.primary]
    connection = "postgresql://graph-node:let-me-in@localhost:5432/graph-node"
    weight = 1
    pool_size = 10
    
    [chains]
    ingestor = "block_ingestor_node"
    [chains.mainnet]
    shard = "primary"
    protocol = "ethereum"
    provider = [
      { label = "peering", url = "$RPC_NODE", features = [ "archive", "traces" ] },
    ]
    
    [deployment]
    [[deployment.rule]]
    shard = "primary"
    indexers = [ "default" ]
    ```

2. Stop `graph-node` instance.
3. Start it back with a Firehose only provider

    ```
    [general]

    [store]
    [store.primary]
    connection = "postgresql://graph-node:let-me-in@localhost:5432/graph-node"
    weight = 1
    pool_size = 10

    [chains]
    ingestor = "block_ingestor_node"
    [chains.mainnet]
    shard = "primary"
    protocol = "ethereum"
    provider = [
      { label = "firehose", details = { type = "firehose", url = "$FIREHOSE_ENDPOINT", token = "$STREAMING_FAST_API_TOKEN", features = [ "compression", "filters" ] }},
    ]

    [deployment]
    [[deployment.rule]]
    shard = "primary"
    indexers = [ "default" ]
    ```

Yields error message `Apr 27 16:03:14.931 ERRO the net version for chain mainnet has changed from 1 to 0 since the last time we ran, component: BlockStore`. 

Weirdly, the network seems to still be configured correctly, so maybe it's more a warning or maybe we should just ignore `net_version` and keep only `genesis_hash` check.
   
   

### Relevant log output

_No response_

### IPFS hash

_No response_

### Subgraph name or link to explorer

_No response_

### Some information to help us out

- [ ] Tick this box if this bug is caused by a regression found in the latest release.
- [ ] Tick this box if this bug is specific to the hosted service.
- [X] I have searched the issue tracker to make sure this issue is not a duplicate.

### OS information

macOS

comment.body: That is still relevant AFAIK. The `net_version` could be ignored and we only rely on the genesis block. Would miss someone mixing up ETH classic endpoint and ETH Mainnet endpoints. I feel this is a relative low possibility in the wild, we would still find mixing up two different networks.
